Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Cognitive VHF Radar System Approach to Study Ionospheric Irregularities
Award.AbstractNarration: This project is to build, test, and deploy a new coherent imaging radar system at Huancayo Observatory in Peru that will enable continuous monitoring of the plasma structuring in the equatorial ionosphere. The new VHF (very high frequency) radar, operating at 50 MHz, will utilize cognitive sensing techniques in order to allow the radar to respond dynamically to the sensed environment by changing operating modes to optimize the received signal. The radar system will complement upper atmospheric sensing instrumentation currently deployed at Huancayo as well as the nearby incoherent scatter radar system at Jicamarca Radio Observatory. The ionospheric observations acquired by the new radar will be used to address several questions regarding climatological dependencies of the generation and evolution of equatorial plasma irregularities. Several graduate and undergraduate students will be involved in the design, installation, and operation of the radar hardware. The proposed implementation of cognitive radar technology is potentially transformative for upper atmospheric remote sensing, and this topic will be the focus of new graduate curriculum development at the host institution. In addition, several aspects of radar engineering and data analysis will be incorporated into an existing undergraduate seminar course. The project will further promote international collaboration between the US and Peru.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project established a low-power VHF coherent imaging radar system in Huancayo, Peru, near the Andes. The system?s full capabilities and operation has not been fully exploited yet due to ITAR restrictions, natural disasters in the local area, faulty products from one of the vendors, and unforeseen power  instability conditions in the zone. Nevertheless, the instrument was placed in Huancayo Observatory that belongs to the Geophysical Institute of Peru. The management and operation of the radar has been established through a cooperative agreement between Penn State and the Geophysical Institute of Peru. The radaris oriented perpendicular to the Earth?s magnetic field, it is sensitive enough to capture equatorial plasma instabilities that develop in the ionosphere. These types of plasma instabilities can cause disruption to satellite communications, GPS navigation systems, and in general to any artificial space device that orbits the Earth.

This system has been given the name Cognitive Interferometric Radar Imager (CIRI) based on its potential cognitive sensing characteristics. This project carried out theoretical analysis to automatically recognize the current plasma instability forming in the ionosphere, and then switch to a transmission waveform that is able to improve the study of certain aspects of the event. A major effort in this project was dedicated toward the development of a cognitive routine that has potential to be utilized for optimizing the returns from the mentioned plasma instabilities.

This radar will benefit current and future projects including: compressive sensing and imaging; accessing large datasets that will be stored on publicly available repositories; connecting students and communities of scientists from developing countries; training future engineers and scientists.The instrument provides a unique opportunity for Penn State to continue its collaborative international research efforts and science education.

The instrument developed under this effort is available for community use under a collaborative agreement. This grant supported many undergraduate and graduate students. In particular, two MS theses, and one PhD theses as well several international and national conference papers. New opportunities of research collaboration can be developed to further Penn State contributions to assess space science problems that afflict society.
